title: Wednesday, 16th October 2019

Wirecard has fully deniedthe allegations from the FT again, mentioning that the article is a compilation of false and misleading allegations, which have already been raised by FT’s journalist over the past few months and which were already fully refuted by Wirecard many times before.

BE11:16am

No further questions, m'lud!

FATDAZ @marktime when you say fiddling I assume you mean playing the violin lol
11:17 am
BE11:17am

While it is always difficult to make up one’s own mind with all these allegations, they seem to be largely unfounded as: 1) the FT’s article is still based on the whistle-blower’s allegations report published at the beginning of the year, which has been fully refuted by the Rajah & Tann (independent layers) report published last March; 2) the Dubai subsidiary is audited globally by EY and,following the whistle-blower’s allegations, EY has completed all the required verifications before approving the 2018 accounts (Wirecard has finally hired a local auditor for Dubai last month,as it is now mandatory since 2019); 3) the transaction volumes in question are not huge (c. EUR4bn volumes per year over 2016-17 from 34 clients, representing only c. 5% of the group’s transaction volumes over the period); 4) Wirecard stated that the contribution from Al Alam mentioned by the FT istotally wrong,as Al Alam is a small partner (among hundreds of partners) and its revenue/EBITDA contribution is negligible at the group level.

Delta1_ETF ASC + 20%

Irish HF guy @Puntino, I just read the EY audit report to the members of Wirecard AG, it does not inspire confidence. Martin Dahman is the signatory from EY. It is highly unusual to have the Irish entity and perhaps some other group companies audited by differing firms.
FATDAZ @marktime Lol and yes indeed

BE11:19am

BE11:20am

n our view, the key issue of contention in the article is the allegation that there are strong indications that much of the payment processing by Al Alam could not have taken place. The basis of the FT allegation is that 15 of 34 clients contacted by the FT said they had never heard of Al Alam. Furthermore the FT questioned how Wirecard could process payments by seemingly defunct businesses. However, it is not surprising that Wirecard customers had not have heard of Al Alam, as third-party acquirers play a white-labelling role and the contract partner is usually a Wirecard company. Regarding the revenues with seemingly defunct businesses, assuming the data in the sheets is reliable, we suspect trailing effects or the omission of a re-naming by Wirecard but expect a more detailed explanation from the company. Furthermore, the FT questioned EY’s oversight of Wirecard’s relationship with Al Alam, which obviously should cast doubt on the general unqualified audit opinion in a tendentious way. This was underpinned by a leaked e-mail conversation between Wirecard employees, dealing with the topic to prevent an external impairment test. In fact, nothing suspicious or illegal is revealed in this conversation. On the contrary, from an economic perspective, unnecessary impairment tests should be avoided by a company as they produce needless costs, which is why the conversation should be fully comprehensible.

Electric Dragon I think the Kepler bod needs to be refreshed on the distinction between "refuted" and "denied".
BE11:21am

An so on and so on.

BE11:21am

Overall, there is little cause for concern as the substance of the allegations was already addressed in previous FT articles and therefore provides nothing new for the market. ... Comparing the current article with previous ones, we gained the impression that the FT already had the detailed information and the leaked documents at an earlier point in time which raises the question as to why this wasn’t published earlier. Nonetheless, we see little probability that the allegations prove to be true and see no threat to our long-term investment case.

This would have helped her prove she had a valid ticket at the time of travel. I would also agree bus inspectors are rare and she was unlucky

BE11:26am

UBS with the summary:

BE11:26am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
FY19 sales growth of 13% was broadly in line with UBSe (12.5%), although EU was stronger (12% vs UBSe 9.5%) and US was weaker at (9% vs UBSe 11%). Retail gross margin was down 250bps yoy at 47.4%, in line with guidance and UBSe. Total operating costs were in line with UBSe, although marketing costs were lower than expected. PBT was in line with guidance at £33.1m. £222m capex was broadly in line with UBSe but YE net debt of £90.5m was slightly below ~£100m guidance given a larger than expected increase in payables.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
1) The automation equipment in Eurohub that drove the P3 warning is now working normally; 2) Disruption in the US warehouse is ongoing. Clearance of unsold stock is expected to continue and there is still low availability of high ASP stock; 3) P4 sales growth was strong at 15%, with orders +20%.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
In the past, ASOS has provided specific sales and margin guidance for the following year and the mid-term. Today there is no FY20 guidance (apart from ~£150m capex, as mentioned at the P3 results), but management has confirmed a 'solid start' to FY20. We currently forecast 15.5% total sales growth, £54m PBT and £153m capex for FY20.
Valuation: Neutral, Price Target £28
We value ASOS using a DCF with 10% WACC, 2% TGR and 6% terminal EBIT margin.

BE11:27am

And Investec

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Profits are in line with expectations while the outlook suggests ASOS has made a solid start to FY20. Issues at the Euro
Hub appear to be resolved, but ongoing work is required for the US Atlanta warehouse where management believes it is
progressing well. We expect no changes to market forecasts today which may lead to some relief. Whilst news flow
appears to be improving (we note ASOS Design is now showing encouraging signs) and forecasts are stabilising, there
is still significant forecast risk, in our view.

BE11:27am

Reporting details
 PBT was £33.1m, -8% YoY, and in line with expectations ranging from £30m to £35m.
 P4 sales were +15% versus Q3 +11%. Discrete data is limited, but sales appear robust in the UK with full-year sales +15%
in line with Q3 YTD +16%, whilst EU sales are +17% (vs Q3 +5%) now the Euro Hub warehouse issues are resolved. The
US remains weak at +7% (Q3: +12%) where availability issues (due to the Atlanta warehouse transition) continue to impact
growth.
 Retail gross margins at -250bps are in line with expectations, implying gross margins were down -440bps in H2 (H1: -60bps),
in part reflecting increased investment in promotion over H2 as anticipated as well as increased stock clearance following
the backlog of orders built up due to warehouse-related operational challenges.
 ASOS own brand/ASOS Design participation appears to have improved and is now 40% having been as low as 35% at H1.
This is encouraging although we suspect the performance was in part buoyed by unfulfilled orders for 3rd party brands in the
US, pushing demand towards ASOS Design.
Outlook and guidance
 No formal guidance for FY20 or even medium-term guidance has been issued today (consensus FY20 sales growth: +15%
and EBIT margin: 2%). However, the outlook statement suggests ASOS has made “a solid start to FY20” and that its ambition
is to “deliver sustainable long term increases in sales, profitability and cashflow”. Valuation: FY20E PE is 54.8x.

dd do like asos stuff ha!
BE11:28am

And Barclays:

TrapAdvisor @wayneJ i worked with a fair few different HoR, the strategy that worked best was the guy who worked his conkers off - no one had any comback to any criticism he could have
11:28 am
BE11:29am

The ASOS results this morning were hotly awaited given multiple operational issues in the last year. They answer some, but definitely not all, of the questions. On the positive, P4 trading is a bit better than expected, FY19 net debt is a bit less (and there are no new negatives on liquidity), the tone suggests warehousing inventory issues in the EU and US are on track to be resolved, and they have made a “solid start to FY20”. On the negative, they haven’t guided for FY20 or beyond in the statement beyond a comment on capex (in line), which leaves people in the dark on how to think about a growth margin recovery. That said, we don’t think there is a reason for consensus EBITDA / PBT to move this year – and building credibility in guiding on anything beyond that was going to be challenging anyway. There may be more after the results presentation but our first take is that there should be some relief in the shares this morning. We are Equal Weight.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

Which is an incremental negative to the wider "Chinese demand stalling" narrative that is the main thing driving all miners.

BE11:39am

Goldman can summarise:

BE11:39am

Key points
Pilbara ore shipments came in at 86.1mn tonnes, modestly ahead of Bloomberg consensus expectations of 85.8mn. This was +6% yoy and +10% qoq.
Alumina production was down 7% yoy, due to a planned maintenance service at Yarwun that led to an extended 35-day shutdown, and a small impact on production at Queensland Alumina (a non-managed JV) which was also impacted by maintenance works.
Aluminum production was down 3% yoy, due to a safety shutdown at ISAL and an earlier than planned pot-lining replacement at Kitimat.
Oyu Tolgoi underground project: shaft 2/the primary production shaft remains on track for commissioning in October. In the past quarter, a central heating plant, shaft 2 jaw crusher system and surface discharge conveyor was installed.

2s10s @fatdaz: that's really interesting about using video.
wayneJ @FATDAZ - I do wonder about video - a lot of traditional buy side shops have seriously poor infrastructure - one place I worked at had one 100MBps line shared amongst several hundred people - so I doubted a video stream would work (the PCs were ancient as well etc)
A. M. (morning all)
11:39 am
BE11:40am

Guidance
Pilbara reiterated its shipment guidance of 320-330 mn t.

Bauxite production guidance cut to c54 mn t (previously 56mn t to 59 mn t) and alumina production, which was revised down to c7.7 mt tn (previously 8.1 to 8.4 mn t). This is due to 1) Bauxite - being impacted by lower production from Pacific refineries, downtime to address new mine commissioning items and 1Q impact from weather; 2) Alumina - maintenance works in Pacific refineries.
Aluminium production guidance is now expected to be at the lower end of
guidance (3.2 to 3.4 mn tonnes), reflecting lower volumes at ISAL, Kitimat and non-managed Becancour smelters.

Q3/19 production was a touch weaker than expected (-3%); however,
sales were 13% lower, particularly the higher value pellets (-28%) which have a greater impact to Labrador's royalty revenue. Positively, operations appear to have returned to normal following the impact of flooding in Q2/19, with full-year production guidance unchanged. However, lagging sales could have a negative impact on Labrador's 2019 earnings, unless the company achieves record Q4/19 shipments.

BE11:42am

Rio Tinto’s Q3’19 production was strong. Iron Ore shipments ran at
341Mtpa, +8% JPMe, (our forecasts were conservative to reflect
maintenance). Copper output was +13% JPMe due to higher grades at
KUC and a strong quarter at Escondida. 2019 guidance was maintained
for iron ore shipments at 320-330Mt (JPMe 328Mt), but alumina and
bauxite guidance was cut due to maintenance & weather issues. RIO’s
recovering iron ore production, following Vale’s Q3 recovery,
are key factors in a ~5% fall in the iron price today to $84/t. However
we reiterate our OW recommendation given RIO’s attractive valuation
vs peers, best-in-class balance sheet and potential for leading capital
returns. Our Dec'20 PT falls modestly to £54.90/sh from £55.00/sh on
incorporating Q3’19 production results.

Barratt Developments this morning released a trading update for the first 15 weeks of its financial year (from July 1st). Sales rates in the period were 0.72, in line with the same period of 2018; however, the comparative period contained two respoke design and build arrangements and sales rates are up c.4% once these are excluded. Barratt has operated off an average of 374 active outlets in the period, up from 365 at the same time in 2018. The increased number of outlets and better sales rates are likely to give comfort around further volume growth in the current year.

BE11:53am

Barratt this morning released a trading update ahead of its AGM for the first 15 weeks of its new financial year, which we followed up with a conversation with management. Key points are:
Home completions were up 14% over the same period last year. Management pointed out that approximately half of this increase was a result of build schedule timing, and they reiterated their existing full-year guidance for c.3% growth in completions.
Underlying LFL house price inflation for Barratt is broadly in-line with the UK average at c.1-2%.
Build cost inflation remains stable at 3-4%.

Total forward sales volumes in the order book is broadly flat YoY (+0.5%), however the mix has slightly shifted: Private sales are down 5%, compensated with more affordable (+3.8%) and more JVs (+9.5%).
Forward sales ASP is down 2.9%, driven by JVs: private sales are up 1.3%, affordable are up 3.7%, but JVs down 28.3% (driven by mix).
Management reiterated that their group ASP would trend down from £289k per unit in 2018, towards £275k per unit, as they finish trading out of high-ASP London developments.
Management intend to be traded out of London by December 2019/January 2020, so high ASP sales will potentially be weighted towards the first half of Barratt’s financial year (Jul-Dec 2019), with a reduction in the second half of the financial year (Jan-Jun 2020).
Subject to AGM approval, Barratt will pay a combined final and special dividend of 36.8p per share on 5 November 2019.

BE11:57am

Stamp duty receipts have doubled since 2011 to £8.4bn, driven by higher house prices and tax rates (on more expensive properties) and the surcharge for investors and second home buyers. The Help to Buy scheme has boosted new build transactions (up by 54% in five years), while second-hand transactions are down by 16% from a recent peak. London and South East housing activity has slowed considerably and had a knock-on effect to RMI activity, with softer demand for a wide range of building products. The Construction Products Association is forecasting a 2% fall in private housing RMI volumes in 2019 following a 1% decline last year.

BE11:58am

With a Budget and General Election on the horizon, could the new Chancellor announce significant SDLT reforms? The campaigning thinktank, Onward, believes he should and has proposed a complete overhaul of the stamp duty system. In short, it recommends stamp duty should be abolished for all purchases of a main home under £500k and to halve current rates for purchases over the same amount. This would save a purchaser of an average London home c£13k. The estimated cost of the proposed cuts (c£3bn) could be balanced by a number of other small tax changes.

Blank canvas Markets Live is essential market commentary - nothing like it elsewhere for me
BE11:58am

Which sectors would benefit? A cut to stamp duty would boost both new build and second-hand housing activity, with more of a benefit likely for the latter given new build continues to be supported by Help to Buy. The Estate Agents, particularly Fox to n s, would be obvious beneficiaries. Within the Housebuilders, McCarthy & Stone# would be helped by more liquidity in the second-hand market, while those with a higher ASP and/or South East bias (Berkeley, Countryside, Crest Nicholson and Redrow#) would see a relative boost. Increased RMI activity should follow higher housing transactions, helpingthose with a high RMI exposure –Travis Perkins, Eurocell#, Howden and Grafton. We also highlightIbstock and Forterra, which generate around a third of their revenues from the operationally geared RMI end market
